Award.AwardTitle: Fort Peck Community College Eci Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to expand the STEM instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricula offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will inform the body of knowledge about strategies that attract, retain and graduate American Indian students in engineering. The Fort Peck Community College (FPCC) will develop a Pre-Engineering Associate of Science (AS) degree program that is transferrable to a bachelor-degree program in Engineering or a related STEM field. The overall purpose of this work is to increase the number of American Indian students pursuing STEM career pathways and achieving STEM degrees at FPCC. The project addresses a growing need for engineers in the region, some of which can be attributed to region's fossil fuel and renewable energy activities. It is important to increase the number of STEM majors and graduates at FPCC as a means to assist Assiniboine and Sioux tribal members to enter these high-growth sectors of the workforce. The project expands FPCC's degree offerings to include a new AS degree in Pre-Engineering to meet the growing need for engineers in the region, use promising strategies from emerging research on community colleges to improve instruction and student achievement in mathematics, build innovative supports to help students complete STEM associate degrees at FPCC and matriculate to STEM bachelor degrees, and expand the college's undergraduate research capacity in STEM fields.

The project builds on and advances research on promising practices from emerging community college research to promote increased student math proficiency and success in STEM fields through early assessment, curriculum redesign and targeted tutoring, expanded access to learning supports, faculty development, transition support from two-year to four-year degrees, and authentic research experiences. The project will address research questions regarding the effect of these promising strategies with American Indian students pursuing STEM degrees. The project is evaluated using a multi-dimensional approach that utilizes both qualitative and quantitative methods for collecting data. The evaluation plan is based on the tenets of a model for return on investment specifically designed for TCUs and based on the work of Phillips and Phillips. These measures and data elements will be used to evaluate how well the project is meeting its objectives to help the project leadership make data-driven decisions regarding project implementation and to derive research-based understanding of the impact of the strategies proposed. Formative data will be collected each semester to inform ongoing activities of the project and summative data will be used to make determinations regarding project successes, strengths, challenges, and recommendations for next steps.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
• A new Pre-Engineering Associate of Science degree program has been developed and approved.

 

  • Articulation Agreements for the Pre-Engineering program between FPCC and the College of Engineering at Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman have been developed, approved, and signed.

 

  • 11 new STEM courses, developed for the Pre-Engineering degree, were added to the STEM curriculum at FPCC.

 

  • 18 students enrolled in the Pre-Engineering Associate of Science degree program at FPCC. Only 2 students graduated with Associate of Science in Pre-Engineering. 1 student transferred to MSU, Bozeman where he is finishing BS in Mechanical Engineering. Several students changed their major to Associate of Science in general studies. The majority of students entering FPCC have very poor Math background. They cannot pass Calculus I. Only 7% of entering freshmen in 2019/2020 were ready for college level Math courses. Several students in the Pre-Engineering program were capable of completing their degree, but they were not willing to put the time and effort.

 

  • All FPCC STEM faculty received STEM training and professional development experiences.

 

  • Physics/Pre-Engineering Lab has been established. Equipment and supplies for the  research and the science Lab were provided.

 

  • Computers, wireless internet access, Computer Based Math Instructions & Assessment Software (ALEKS), and Placement programs have been provided by the TCUP Eci project. This enhanced FPCC students and faculty access to technology and the internet.

 

  • The quality of the STEM instructions has been enhanced significantly by hiring qualified STEM faculty. However, some STEM instructors are still reluctant to utilize new educational technology to improve STEM student learning.

 

  • The Undergraduate Research program was the most successful component of the TCUP Eci project. The research and instructional capacities at FPCC have been enhanced and expanded significantly.

 

  • 9 FPCC professors and 4 from MSU participated in the TCUP Summer Undergraduate Research Project. 12 undergraduate summer research projects were implemented.

 

  • 114 students from FPCC and the local High Schools participated in the TCUP Eci Summer Research program and 145 students enrolled in the summer Math and science program.

 

  • 300 STEM stipends were provided by the TCUP Eci project.

 

  • Dual credit/Early College enrollment articulation agreements was established between FPCC and the High Schools. 271 high school students enrolled in Dual Credit/Early College courses.10 students enrolled in the FPCC Calculus I in Spring 2020 and 5 students in Spring 2019.

 

  • 223 students received STEM Tutoring. Some students mentioned that they could not pass their Math courses without the tutoring.

 

  • The Math courses showed improvement during the last 5 years (2015/2016 to 2019/2020). The Math enrollment increased 9.38% in 2019/2020 and 7.38% in 2018/2019. However, the Math enrollment has been decreasing by 14.83% annually from 2014/2015 to 2017/2018. This decrease in the Math enrollment reflects the decrease in the overall student enrollment at FPCC.

 

  • The math completion rate (C or higher) for the academic year 2019/2020 was 41.71%. It was 29.5% in the year 2014/2015. The Math completion rate increased by 12.21% in 2019/2020 compared to 2014/2015. The average Math completion rate for the last 5 academic years was 41.40%. The highest Math completion rate was 48.13% in 2018/2019 and the lowest was 33.50% in 2015/2016. On average the Math completion rate increased 11.9% in the last 5 years compared to 2014/2015.

 

  • Students continue to struggle in the algebra courses. They do better in Basic Math. Only 12% of the students taking Intro. & Intermediate Algebra passed (C or higher) in the academic year 2019-2020. When combining Intro. & Intermediate Algebra with Basic Math, 36 % of the students passed in the academic year 2019-2020. The average completion rate (C or above) in the developmental math courses for the last five years was 25.23%.

 

  • The science courses did not change much during the last 5 years (2015/2016 to 2019/2020). The Science annual enrollment held steady at 95 over the last 5 years. It was 94 in 2014/2015. It was the highest (105) in 2018/2019 and the lowest (80) in 2016/2017.

 

  • The average Science completion rate was 45.49% over the last 5 years. It was the highest at 65.6% in 2015/2016 and lowest at 33.75% in 2016/2017. The Science completion rate was 37.23% in 2019/2020 and 52.1% in 2014/2015. It decreases by 14.87% in 2019/2020 compared to 2014/2015. On average the Science completion rate decreased by 6.61% in the last 5 years compared to 2014/2015.

Last Modified: 09/20/2020
Modified by: Ali Wehbe
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A new Pre-Engineering Associate of Science degree program has been developed and approved. Articulation Agreements for the Pre-Engineering program between FPCC and the College of Engineering at Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman have been developed, approved, and signed. 11 new STEM courses, developed for the Pre-Engineering degree, were added to the STEM curriculum at FPCC. 18 students enrolled in the Pre-Engineering Associate of Science degree program at FPCC. Only 2 students graduated with Associate of Science in Pre-Engineering. 1 student transferred to MSU, Bozeman where he is finishing BS in Mechanical Engineering. Several students changed their major to Associate of Science in general studies. The majority of students entering FPCC have very poor Math background. They cannot pass Calculus I. Only 7% of entering freshmen in 2019/2020 were ready for college level Math courses. Several students in the Pre-Engineering program were capable of completing their degree, but they were not willing to put the time and effort. All FPCC STEM faculty received STEM training and professional development experiences. Physics/Pre-Engineering Lab has been established. Equipment and supplies for the research and the science Lab were provided. Computers, wireless internet access, Computer Based Math Instructions & Assessment Software (ALEKS), and Placement programs have been provided by the TCUP Eci project. This enhanced FPCC students and faculty access to technology and the internet. The quality of the STEM instructions has been enhanced significantly by hiring qualified STEM faculty. However, some STEM instructors are still reluctant to utilize new educational technology to improve STEM student learning. The Undergraduate Research program was the most successful component of the TCUP Eci project. The research and instructional capacities at FPCC have been enhanced and expanded significantly. 9 FPCC professors and 4 from MSU participated in the TCUP Summer Undergraduate Research Project. 12 undergraduate summer research projects were implemented. 114 students from FPCC and the local High Schools participated in the TCUP Eci Summer Research program and 145 students enrolled in the summer Math and science program. 300 STEM stipends were provided by the TCUP Eci project. Dual credit/Early College enrollment articulation agreements was established between FPCC and the High Schools. 271 high school students enrolled in Dual Credit/Early College courses.10 students enrolled in the FPCC Calculus I in Spring 2020 and 5 students in Spring 2019. 223 students received STEM Tutoring. Some students mentioned that they could not pass their Math courses without the tutoring. The Math courses showed improvement during the last 5 years (2015/2016 to 2019/2020). The Math enrollment increased 9.38% in 2019/2020 and 7.38% in 2018/2019. However, the Math enrollment has been decreasing by 14.83% annually from 2014/2015 to 2017/2018. This decrease in the Math enrollment reflects the decrease in the overall student enrollment at FPCC. The math completion rate (C or higher) for the academic year 2019/2020 was 41.71%. It was 29.5% in the year 2014/2015. The Math completion rate increased by 12.21% in 2019/2020 compared to 2014/2015. The average Math completion rate for the last 5 academic years was 41.40%. The highest Math completion rate was 48.13% in 2018/2019 and the lowest was 33.50% in 2015/2016. On average the Math completion rate increased 11.9% in the last 5 years compared to 2014/2015. Students continue to struggle in the algebra courses. They do better in Basic Math. Only 12% of the students taking Intro. & Intermediate Algebra passed (C or higher) in the academic year 2019-2020. When combining Intro. & Intermediate Algebra with Basic Math, 36 % of the students passed in the academic year 2019-2020. The average completion rate (C or above) in the developmental math courses for the last five years was 25.23%. The science courses did not change much during the last 5 years (2015/2016 to 2019/2020). The Science annual enrollment held steady at 95 over the last 5 years. It was 94 in 2014/2015. It was the highest (105) in 2018/2019 and the lowest (80) in 2016/2017. The average Science completion rate was 45.49% over the last 5 years. It was the highest at 65.6% in 2015/2016 and lowest at 33.75% in 2016/2017. The Science completion rate was 37.23% in 2019/2020 and 52.1% in 2014/2015. It decreases by 14.87% in 2019/2020 compared to 2014/2015. On average the Science completion rate decreased by 6.61% in the last 5 years compared to 2014/2015.
